images.altText: Picture showing the transparent upper torso of a human with the bones visible

pageData.text: To maintain a stable internal state, the body must take in oxygen and expel carbon dioxide. The respiratory system facilitates the exchange of atmospheric oxygen with carbon dioxide generated by metabolism. In this investigation, several aspects of the respiratory system will be examined, with special attention to assessments of respiratory function.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes
 Activity 1: Assessing Respiratory Rate (RR) at Rest – 10 minutes
 Activity 2: Assessing Respiratory Rate (RR) After Activity – 15 minutes
 Activity 3: Assessing Tidal Volume (TV) – 10 minutes
 Activity 4: Assessing Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) – 10 minutes
 Activity 5: Assessing Vital Capacity (VC) – 10–15 minutes
 Activity 6: Calculating Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) – 5 minutes
 Activity 7: Assessing Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) – 10 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Note for instructors:
pageData.text: This investigation involves the student providing respiratory test results to the instructor as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

pageData.subTitle: Note for students:
pageData.text: The respiratory tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: Calculator
Timing device, such as a stopwatch or a cell phone with timer function
Chair or other seating that allows you to sit upright with both feet on the floor
Meter stick or tape measure to determine your height (if unknown) and assist with placement of lung volume bag mouthpiece

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Describe key structures of the respiratory system and their functions.
Explain the roles of the respiratory system in homeostasis.
Define specific measures of respiratory function and relate them to restrictive and obstructive respiratory disorders.
Perform and interpret assessments of respiratory function.

pageData.text: Sleep apnea is a category of potentially serious sleep disorders in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts unexpectedly, resulting in poor-quality sleep. Snoring loudly and feeling tired after a full night's sleep are both symptoms of sleep apnea. It is estimated that in the United States, 3-7% of men and 2-5% of women suffer from sleep apnea. Chronic sleep problems can cause obesity, depression, coronary heart disease, weakened immune response, and diabetes

The most common treatment for sleep apnea is to sleep wearing a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine. This machine pumps a steady flow of oxygen into the airways to prevent them from collapsing, which typically defines sleep apnea disorders. With their airways unobstructed, the patient no longer wakes up repeatedly to resume breathing.

Image attribution: Photo by John Ramspott, available under Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic license at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/jramspott/7355393770/

pageData.desc: A dummy head wearing the breathing apparatus for a CPAP machine over its nose and mouth.
pageData.altText: A dummy head wearing the breathing apparatus for a CPAP machine over its nose and mouth.

pageData.text: The respiratory system is responsible for gas exchange—the inhalation of oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and the exhalation of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>). The lungs, conducting airways, and the diaphragm are key structures of the system.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Respiratory System

pageData.subTitle: Lungs and Diaphragm
pageData.text: Human lungs are sponge-like organs found in the thoracic (chest) cavity. The right lung has 3 lobes and is larger than the bilobed left lung, as the heart occupies more space on the left side. The diaphragm is a domed, sheet-like muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

pageData.subTitle: Breathing
pageData.text:
During inhalation, the diaphragm contracts, and air is pulled through the conducting airways into the lungs.
During exhalation, the diaphragm relaxes, and air is pushed from the lungs.

pageData.subTitle: Bronchi, Bronchioles, and Alveoli
pageData.text: Air enters the lungs from the trachea through the right and left bronchus. These branching airways lead to bronchioles and end in microscopic air sacs called alveoli. The alveoli are the sites of gas exchange between the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.

pageData.subTitle: Structure and Function of the Respiratory System
pageData.text: The body needs a ready supply of energy. Its principle method of obtaining energy from food is through aerobic cellular respiration. This series of chemical reactions requires oxygen (O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), releases carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), and generates adenosine triphosphate (ATP). ATP is the main energy currency of the cell; all of the body’s physiological processes, from muscle contraction to DNA synthesis, use ATP. Thus, the body must continuously take in O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, while constantly producing CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>.

Not only does the respiratory system ensure that aerobic cellular respiration is able to continue, it also plays a vital role in maintaining the acid-base balance of the blood and other body fluids. A ready supply of energy and the acid- base balance are important components of homeostasis, the dynamically stable internal state of the body that is necessary for health and survival.

CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> dissolves in water (the primary constituent of blood plasma) and forms carbonic acid (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>), a weak acid that promptly dissociates and releases hydrogen ions (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) and bicarbonate ions (HCO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub><sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>), as shown in the equation below. The double arrows in the equation indicate a reversible equilibrium.
CO2 + H2O ⇋ H2CO3 ⇋ H+ + HCO3-

As blood CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> levels rise, more H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub> forms and releases H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>, causing the blood to become more acidic. The respiratory system helps prevent blood pH from becoming too acidic by expelling CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> from the body. CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> removal allows the overall reaction to run in reverse, driving free H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> levels down and forming H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O.

Breathing very quickly and deeply is called <button class=glossary-text>hyperventilation</button>, or “overbreathing.” Hyperventilation can occur due to a panic attack, pain, or various health conditions. When CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> is removed from the body too rapidly, the pH of the blood and other body fluids starts to rise, a condition known as <button class=glossary-text>respiratory alkalosis</button>. Like-wise, if an individual is unable to exhale enough CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, the pH of body fluids will fall, a condition called <button class=glossary-text>respiratory acidosis</button>. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD, discussed below) can lead to respiratory acidosis. Another common cause is sleep apnea, in which an individual temporarily stops breathing while asleep.

The human respiratory system (Figure 1) consists of an upper portion that warms, moistens, and cleanses inhaled air, and a lower portion that conducts air to and from the lungs and facilitates gas exchange in the lungs.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Labeled diagram of the parts of the respiratory system from the nose to the lungs

pageData.text: The upper respiratory system begins with the nostrils, the openings dedicated to taking in air and releasing exhaled breath. The mouth also serves as an opening for the respiratory system. Air that enters through the nostrils passes into the paired nasal cavities. Each is lined with a mucus-producing, that traps inhaled microbes and dust, while warming and moistening the air before it passes to the , or throat.

The lower respiratory system begins with the , or “voice box,” which is composed mainly of cartilage and voluntary muscle. It contains the vocal cords, membranous folds that vibrate to adjust the pitch and tone of vocalizations. To prevent food from entering the larynx, a small flap called the temporarily closes the airway during swallowing. Air then enters the , a tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage within its walls that keep it open. In the chest cavity, the trachea splits into two bronchi: a left main and a right main bronchus. Each bronchus enters a lung and then splits into smaller secondary bronchi, which in turn branch into tertiary bronchi. The bronchi are held open by cartilage plates, although the amount declines with successive branches (Figure 2). Eventually the tiny passage ways have no cartilage in their walls and are known as . Most of the respiratory structures are conducting airways, serving to deliver air to and from the smallest bronchioles. These minute bronchioles, known as terminal bronchioles, open into bubble-like pouches called , which are the locations for gas exchange between the air in the lungs and the bloodstream. The alveoli have very thin epithelial walls and are surrounded by blood capillaries. O2 diffuses from the air inside the alveoli into the blood, and CO2 from the blood into the alveoli. Because of this gas exchange, air expelled from the lungs has a higher concentration of CO2 and a lower concentration of O2 than the air taken in.

Although the gas exchange that occurs in the alveoli is necessary to maintain homeostasis, not all inhaled air is subject to gas exchange. The volume occupied by all the air not involved in gas exchange is known as the <button class=glossary-text>physiological dead space</button> (or total dead space). There are two components to the physiological dead space.

The anatomical dead space is the volume of air in conducting airway structures. Everyone has anatomical dead space; in fact, roughly a third of each resting inhaled or exhaled breath is devoted to anatomical dead space. In addition, certain respiratory disorders render the alveoli incapable of gas exchange. The air volume in these alveoli is the alveolar dead space.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A cross-sectional view of a bronchus and a bronchiole with alveoli as well as a close-up of alveoli and a capillary, with arrows demonstrating gas exchange within alveoli

pageData.text: To ensure effective gas exchange, the lungs must be ventilated through the process of breathing. Movements of the rib cage and a dome-shaped sheet of muscle called the (see ) permit changes in the volume of the thoracic cavity (chest cavity) during breathing.

The lungs must continuously expand and recoil throughout the breathing cycle, so protection from the damaging effects of friction is essential. Each lung is wrapped within two serous membranes known as the pulmonary pleurae, or pleural sac. The visceral pleura adheres closely to the surface of each lung, and the parietal pleura adheres to the thoracic wall. Between the two pleurae is a very thin, fluid-filled space called the (see ). The pleural fluid reduces friction between the membranes as they slide past one another with each breath.

Because air moves from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure, breathing is accomplished by establishing a pressure difference between the air within the lungs and the air outside the body. During inhalation (see Figure 3), also called inspiration, the rib cage is pulled up and out, and the diaphragm is pulled down, increasing lung volume and decreasing pressure.

This lower pressure results in air entering the lungs. During exhalation (see Figure 3), also called expiration, the rib cage moves back down and the diaphragm springs back to its original, higher position. This reduces lung volume and increases air pressure in the lungs, causing air to leave the lungs.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation

pageData.question: Which structure permits changes in the volume of the thoracic cavity during breathing?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The diaphragm is a dome-shaped sheet of muscle separating the chest cavity and abdominal cavities. Along with the rib cage, it permits changes in the volume of the thoracic cavity during breathing.

pageData.question: Which structures protect the lungs from the damaging effects of friction during breathing?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The lungs are protected from friction as they are encased by two pulmonary pleurae between which is the fluid-filled pleural cavity.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The lungs must continuously expand and recoil throughout the breathing cycle. To facilitate this, the rib cage and the diaphragm (a dome-shaped sheet of muscle) move and thus permit changes in the volume of the thoracic cavity (chest cavity). Not only do the lungs need space to expand, but they also need protection from the damaging effects of friction. Each lung is wrapped within two serous membranes known as the pulmonary pleurae: the visceral pleura adheres closely to the surface of each lung, and the parietal pleura adheres to the thoracic wall. Between the two pleurae is a very thin, fluid-filled space called the pleural cavity.

hintData.body: The lungs must continuously expand and recoil throughout the breathing cycle. To facilitate this, the rib cage and the diaphragm (a dome-shaped sheet of muscle) move and thus permit changes in the volume of the thoracic cavity (chest cavity). Not only do the lungs need space to expand, but they also need protection from the damaging effects of friction. Each lung is wrapped within two serous membranes known as the pulmonary pleurae: the visceral pleura adheres closely to the surface of each lung, and the parietal pleura adheres to the thoracic wall. Between the two pleurae is a very thin, fluid-filled space called the pleural cavity.

pageData.subTitle: Measurements of Respiratory Function
pageData.text: Respiratory function can be measured in a variety of ways. The number of breaths may be counted for one minute to determine the . The adult respiratory rate is typically between 12 and 20 breaths (inhalation plus exhalation) per minute, with an average value of 16 breaths per minute. A respiratory rate above 20 breaths per minute is called . A respiratory rate below 12 breaths per minute is called . Respiratory rate can be affected by a range of factors, including physical activity, emotional state, and medications. A device called a spirometer may be used to assess lung volumes and capacities (see Figure 4).

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph of the change in volume of the lung during normal breathing and deep breathing. The inspiratory reserve, tidal, expiratory reserve, and the residual volume regions are labeled. Functional reserve capacity is shown to be made up of ERV and RV values. Inspiratory capacity is shown to be the sum of the RV and TV values. Vital capacity is the sum of the ERV, TV, and RV values, and the total lung capacity is the sum of all lung volumes.

pageData.text: are measurements of the amount of air in the lungs. There are four main respiratory volumes (see ). Their average values vary between men and women, with men tending to have larger lung volumes (see Table 1).

text: <button class=glossary-text>Tidal volume (TV)</button> is the amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest.
<button class=glossary-text> Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)</button> is the amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.
<button class=glossary-text>Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)</button> is the amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.
<button class=glossary-text>Residual volume (RV)</button> is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation.

pageData.text: are gauges of respiratory function calculated by adding two or more lung volumes (see Table 2).

text:
is the maximum amount that can be expelled from the lungs after a forceful inhalation: VC = TV + IRV + ERV. Since VC changes with age and size, the following formulas can be used to predict an individual’s VC in liters:
Women: VC = (0.041 × height in cm) – (0.018 × age in years) – 2.69
Men: VC = (0.052 × height in cm) – (0.022 × age in years) – 3.6
is the maximum amount that can be inhaled after a typical TV exhalation: IC = TV + IRV.
is the amount retained in the lungs after a normal TV exhalation: FRC = ERV + RV.
is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation: TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV.

pageData.question:
How can total lung capacity (TLC) be calculated?
  • Tidal volume (TV)
  • Vital capacity (VC)
  • Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • Inspiratory capacity (IC)
  • Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
  • Functional residual capacity (FRC)
  • Residual volume (RV)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Total lung capacity (TLC) is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation: TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between respiratory volumes and respiratory capacities?

options.text: Respiratory volumes can be used to determine respiratory capacities.
Respiratory measurements in men are called capacities, and in women they are called volumes.
Respiratory volume and respiratory capacity refer to the same measurement.
Respiratory capacities describe percentages of respiratory volumes.
Respiratory volumes are lower when respiratory capacities are higher and vice versa.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Respiratory volumes are used to calculate respiratory capacities.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Respiratory volumes are measurements of the amount of air in the lungs. These measurements can be combined in different ways to calculate respiratory capacities, which are gauges of respiratory function. Total lung capacity, for example, is the maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the four main respiratory volumes. Tidal volume (TV) is the amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest. Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation. Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Based on the average lung volumes for men and women in Table 1, the average TLC for men is 5.8 L and the average TLC for women is 4.2 L.

pageData.text: Although a spirometer is useful for measuring a variety of different aspects of respiratory function, other tools may also be employed to assess the respiratory system. A lung volume bag provides an easy and inexpensive way to measure expiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and vital capacity. A peak flow meter (also called a peak expiratory flow monitor) is used to measure or simply peak flow, defined as the maximum air flow attained during a maximum forced expiration following a maximum inhalation. PEFR is typically expressed in liters per minute. Normal PEFR values vary with age, sex, and height, with men tending to have higher values correlated with larger size. For example, for 20-year-old men, typical expected values range from 554–740 L/min depending on height; for women of the same age, the expected range is 390–529 L/min. A peak flow meter is especially useful for individuals who have been diagnosed with asthma (discussed below) and need to self monitor.

pageData.subTitle: Influences on Respiratory Function
pageData.text: <button class=glossary-text>Respiratory volumes</button> and capacities can vary greatly between individuals, which is why they are so useful as part of diagnostic testing. The respiratory system is in direct contact with the air we inhale from our surroundings. Thus, it is subject to environmental influences including airborne microbes, particulate matter, humidity, and air temperature.

Sex is an important factor in determining <button class=glossary-text>respiratory capacities</button> and volumes. Most of these measurements (excepting tidal volume) tend to increase with height, which is why they tend to be larger in men than in women. Pregnancy greatly impacts a woman’s respiratory test results. As the fetus grows, the expanding uterus pushes the <button class=glossary-text>diaphragm</button> upward, crowding the thoracic cavity. Total lung capacity, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume are all reduced, resulting in reduced vital capacity and functional residual capacity as well. Tidal volume is not affected; however, to provide enough O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> for both herself and her growing fetus, a pregnant woman’s <button class=glossary-text>respiratory rate</button> will increase. <button class=glossary-text>Hyperventilation</button> may sometimes occur, especially late in pregnancy.

As a child grows to adulthood, the respiratory system increases in size, and so do the respiratory volumes and capacities. However, mature individuals age, and beginning around age 35, the respiratory system, including lung tissue, loses resilience. Although total lung capacity usually remains constant, residual volume and functional residual capacity generally increase, while tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, inspiratory capacity, and vital capacity decrease.

<button class=glossary-text>Restrictive airway conditions</button> restrict lung expansion, thus reducing overall lung volume and, consequently, measurements including inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes and residual volume. For example, in <button class=glossary-text>fibrosing alveolitis</button>, the alveolar walls become scarred and thickened. The cause of fibrosing alveolitis is unclear, but it is thought to be an autoimmune disorder. Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that may affect different organs in the body, including the lungs, where it is known as pulmonary tuberculosis. Unlike fibrosing alveolitis, which tends to be diffused, pulmonary tuberculosis results in dense areas of infection that undergo scarring and calcification. Sarcoidosis creates a similar pattern of damage to tuberculosis, but it is not due to an infection. Like fibrosing alveolitis, it may be an autoimmune condition, perhaps triggered by exposure to inhaled particulates.

<button class=glossary-text>Obstructive airway conditions</button> make it difficult to exhale a normal volume of air. As in restrictive airway conditions, inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes are reduced. However, residual volume is elevated.

In asthma, the airways narrow and become obstructed by mucus. PEFR measurements may decline with increasing airway obstruction. The causes of asthma are still unclear; however, they are likely a combination of genetics and the environment. Environmental factors such as cold air, air pollution, and airborne particulates such as dust and pollen can certainly worsen asthma.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary desease (COPD) is an inflammatory disease of the lungs caused by prolonged exposure to smoke or other inhaled irritants. Two important COPD conditions are chronic bronchitis and emphysema. In chronic bronchitis, the <button class=glossary-text>bronchioles</button> are inflamed and produce copious amounts of mucus. In emphysema, the walls of the <button class=glossary-text>alveoli</button> are overexpanded and have lost their elasticity; they are unable to facilitate proper gas exchange.

pageData.question: Most respiratory volume averages are higher in men than in women. Why is this?

options.text: Most of these measurements tend to increase with height.
Most of these measurements tend to increase with weight.
Women have more autoimmune disorders than men.
Men are more often used in scientific research than women.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Sex is an important factor in determining respiratory capacities and volumes. Most of these measurements (excepting tidal volume) tend to increase with height, which is why they tend to be larger in men than in women.

pageData.question: Which of the following factors is LEAST likely to impact an individual’s respiratory test results?

options.text: the air quality of the room

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The most significant factors affecting respiratory capacities and volumes are the individual’s height, age, pregnancy status (in women), and environmental influences.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Respiratory volumes and capacities can vary greatly between individuals, which is why they are so useful as part of diagnostic testing. Several factors impact the determination of respiratory capacities and volumes. Because the respiratory system is in direct contact with the air we inhale from our surroundings, it is subject to environmental influences including airborne microbes, particulate matter, humidity, and air temperature. Sex is also an important factor in that men are taller, on average, than women. Because most of these measurements (excepting tidal volume) tend to increase with height, they tend to be larger in men than in women.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Age is another factor: as a child grows to adulthood, the respiratory system increases in size, and so do the respiratory volumes and capacities. However, as individuals age, beginning around age 35, the respiratory system loses resilience. In women, pregnancy greatly impacts respiratory test results. As the fetus grows, the expanding uterus pushes the diaphragm upward, crowding the thoracic cavity. Total lung capacity, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume are all reduced, resulting in reduced vital capacity and functional residual capacity as well.

pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for Activities 1 through 3 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the lung volume bag and peak flow meter. In Activity 1, count the number of breaths per minute at rest for four trials.  Then, calculate the average respiratory rate. In Activity 2, count the number of breaths per minute after engaging in activity for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate. In Activity 3, breathe into the lung volume bag, then calculate the tidal volume.

This map depicts the workflow for Activities 4-7 of this investigation. In Activity 4, breathe into the lung volume bag, then calculate the expiratory reserve volume. In Activity 5, calculate the estimated vital capacity. Then, breathe into the lung volume bag and measure the actual vital capacity. In Activity 6, calculate the inspiratory reserve volume with data from Activities 3 through 5. In Activity 7, determine the peak expiratory flow rate using the peak flow meter for four trials. Then, calculate the average peak expiratory flow rate.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following lists, in order, the path taken by inhaled air?

bronchioles, bronchi, trachea, larynx, pharynx, alveoli

bronchi, alveoli, larynx, bronchioles, pharynx, trachea

The ribcage moves down and in, and the diaphragm moves up.

The ribcage moves up and out, and the diaphragm moves up.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the instructions before you begin working.
Obtain all materials, including those that are needed but not supplied.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Watch this video to learn how to set up and use the flow meter. You may want to have your computer or mobile device nearby to replay the video for reference.
Prepare the lung volume bag:

• Insert the cardboard mouthpiece in the opening of the lung volume bag, making sure that roughly 3 cm of the mouthpiece protrudes from the bag opening.
  • Secure the mouthpiece in the opening of the lung volume bag using a rubber band.
  • Remove as much air as possible from the bag by rolling it from the bottom toward the mouthpiece. If there is already a good bit of air in the bag, it may be helpful to first flatten the bag on a flat surface such as a tabletop. Alternatively, you may remove excess air by placing one foot on a chair, flattening the bag against your thigh with one hand, and pulling the bag through with the other hand. Leave the bag rolled until ready for use. Use this same procedure each time you need to remove air from the lung volume bag.
Prepare the peak flow meter:

• Place the slightly larger end of the plastic mouthpiece into the peak flow meter opening.
  • Slide the red indicator all the way to the bottom of the measurement scale. Do not move the red, yellow, and green markers located to the right of the measurement scale.
    Note: Your peak flow meter is packaged with an instructional insert. Please use this manual as your primary source of instructions. However, you should keep the insert for reference.
In Activity 1, you will calculate your <button class=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> while at rest.
Sit upright with both feet on the floor for two minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Count the number of breaths you take in one minute. A breath consists of one inhalation and one exhalation. Repeat three more times and record your results in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Calculate the average number of breaths per minute and record this value in Data Table 1. You can calculate the average by adding the breaths per minute from each trial and dividing the total number of breaths by the number of trials (four).
In Activity 2, you will calculate your <button class=glossary-text>respiratory rate (RR)</button> after physical activity.
Run in place for two minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Immediately after stopping, count the number of breaths for one minute. Repeat three more times and record the results in Data Table 2. Wait for two minutes between each trial.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Calculate the average number of breaths per minute, and record this value in Data Table 2.
In Activity 3, you will use the lung volume bag to measure your <button class=glossary-text>tidal volume (TV)</button>.
Make sure there is no air in the lung volume bag.

Sit upright with both feet on the floor for at least two minutes. Allow at least five minutes if you have
just completed Activity 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Insert the mouthpiece into your mouth. Breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth for three normal breaths.
Immediately after exhaling the third breath, fold the bag over just below the mouthpiece to prevent air from escaping.

Remove the mouthpiece and rubber band without allowing air to escape from the bag. Roll the bag, pushing air towards the bottom as you go. When you cannot roll the bag further, record the total volume in Data Table 3.

Divide the total volume recorded in step 5 by the number of breaths (three) to calculate the tidal volume.
Record this value in Data Table 3.
In Activity 4, you will use the lung volume bag to measure your <button class=glossary-text> expiratory reserve volume (ERV)</button>.
Make sure there is no air in the lung volume bag.
Sit upright with both feet on the floor. If you took a break and moved about prior to this activity, wait at least two minutes before proceeding to the next step.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take a normal breath, then insert the mouthpiece and exhale as much air as you can as forcefully as you can..
Immediately after completing the exhalation, fold the bag over just below the mouthpiece to prevent air from escaping. Keep it folded until the next exhalation.
Repeat steps 3 and 4 two more times.

Fold the top of the bag over and remove the mouthpiece and rubber band, without allowing air to escape from the bag. Roll the bag, pushing air towards the bottom as you go. When you cannot roll the bag further, record the total volume in Data Table 4.
Divide the total volume recorded in step 6 by the number of breaths (three) to calculate the expiratory reserve volume. Record this value in Data Table 4.
In Activity 5, you will calculate your estimated vital capacity. Then, you will measure your actual vital capacity using the lung volume bag.

Estimate your vital capacity by using the appropriate formula and enter the result in Data Table 5. Women: VC = (0.041 × height in cm) – (0.018 × age in years) – 2.69
Men: VC = (0.052 × height in cm) – (0.022 × age in years) – 3.6
Make sure there is no air in the lung volume bag.
Sit upright, with both feet on the floor. If you took a break and moved about prior to this step, wait at least two minutes before proceeding to the next step.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take the deepest breath in that you can. Then insert the mouthpiece and breathe out as hard and long as you can.
Immediately after completing the exhalation, fold the bag over just below the mouthpiece to prevent air from escaping. Keep it folded.

Remove the mouthpiece and rubber band, without allowing air to escape from the bag. Roll the bag, pushing air towards the bottom as you go. When you cannot roll the bag further, record the total volume in Data Table 5.

Optional: Repeat the vital capacity measurement two more times, emptying the lung volume bag between each trial. Add all three measured vital capacity values, then divide by three to calculate the average measured vital capacity. Record this value in Data Table 5.
In Activity 6, you will use the results from Activities 3-5 and the equation for vital capacity to calculate your inspiratory reserve volume (IRV).
Complete the first three columns of Data Table 6. by referring to your results from Activities 3–5. (If you determined the average measured vital capacity, use that value in the first column.)

Recall that vital capacity is the sum of tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume:
VC = TV + IRV + ERV

Rearranging this equation allows us to calculate inspiratory reserve volume:
IRV = VC – TV – ERV
Use the equation above to calculate inspiratory reserve volume, then record the value in Data Table 6.
In Activity 7, you will calculate your average <button class=glossary-text>peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR)</button> using the peak flow meter.
Sit upright with both feet on the floor. If you took a break and moved about prior to this activity, wait at least two minutes before proceeding.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take a few deep breaths.
Insert the mouthpiece of the peak flow meter and blow out in a sharp, hard breath. Avoid a long exhalation. Record the PEFR in Data Table 7. under the Trial 1 column. Reset the peak flow meter.

Repeat step 3 three more times and record each trial in Data Table 7. Be sure to reset the peak flow meter after each trial. Add all four PEFR values, then divide by four to calculate the average PEFR. Record this value in Data Table 7.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Discard the used lung volume bag mouthpiece in the household trash. Return the bag and rubber band to your lab kit for storage.
Rinse the peak flow meter mouthpiece with soap and water. Dry with paper towels or allow to air-dry. When dry, store the peak flow monitor with your lab kit materials.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.title: Data Table 1: Assessing Respiratory Rate (RR) at Rest

header.text: Average number of breaths per minute

pageData.title: Data Table 2: Assessing Respiratory Rate (RR) After Activity

header.text: Average number of breaths per minute

text: Compare the values for breathing while at rest sitting vs. breathing while at rest standing. Is there a difference? Why or why not?

pageData.title: Data Table 4: Assessing Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

text: After expelling the expiratory reserve volume, did any air remain in your (or the subject’s) lungs? Explain your answer.

pageData.title: Data Table 6: Calculating Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)
Data Table 7: Assessing Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR)

text: IRV and PEFR are often measured in individuals who may have asthma. Based on the Background for this investigation, and your experience carrying out Activities 6 and 7, how would you expect these values to be affected by asthma?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Labeled diagram of the parts of the respiratory system from the nose to the lungs

pageData.content: Figure 2. Cross sections of a bronchiole and alveolus
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A cross-sectional view of a bronchus and a bronchiole with alveoli as well as a close-up of alveoli and a capillary, with arrows demonstrating gas exchange within alveoli
Figure 3: Two diagrams with arrows demonstrating lung volume increasing during inhalation and decreasing during exhalation

pageData.content: Figure 4. A lung volumes and capacities chart
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph of the change in volume of the lung during normal breathing and deep breathing. The inspiratory reserve, tidal, expiratory reserve, and the residual volume regions are labeled. Functional reserve capacity is shown to be made up of ERV and RV values. Inspiratory capacity is shown to be the sum of the RV and TV values. Vital capacity is the sum of the ERV, TV, and RV values, and the total lung capacity is the sum of all lung volumes.

pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for Activities 1 through 3 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the lung volume bag and peak flow meter. In Activity 1, count the number of breaths per minute at rest for four trials.  Then, calculate the average respiratory rate. In Activity 2, count the number of breaths per minute after engaging in activity for four trials. Then, calculate the average respiratory rate. In Activity 3, breathe into the lung volume bag, then calculate the tidal volume.

This map depicts the workflow for Activities 4-7 of this investigation. In Activity 4, breathe into the lung volume bag, then calculate the expiratory reserve volume. In Activity 5, calculate the estimated vital capacity. Then, breathe into the lung volume bag and measure the actual vital capacity. In Activity 6, calculate the inspiratory reserve volume with data from Activities 3 through 5. In Activity 7, determine the peak expiratory flow rate using the peak flow meter for four trials. Then, calculate the average peak expiratory flow rate.

data.title: Alveoli
data.content: Tiny air sacs in the lungs

data.title: Bradypnea
data.content: A slow respiratory rate, below 12 breaths per minute

data.title: Bronchiole
data.content: Tiny passage ways in the lungs

data.title: Bronchus
data.content: Plural bronchi; one of two large airways that branch from the trachea

data.title: Ciliated epithelium
data.content: Cells with hair-like organelles on the surface

data.title: Diaphragm
data.content: A dome-shaped sheet of muscle,  separates the chest cavity and abdominal cavities

data.title: Epiglottis
data.content: A small flap that prevents food from entering the larynx

data.title: Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
data.content: The amount that can be exhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.

data.title: Fibrosing alveolitis
data.content: A condition when the alveolar walls become scarred and thickened

data.title: Functional residual capacity (FRC)
data.content: The amount retained in the lungs after a normal TV exhalation: FRC = ERV + RV

data.title: Hyperventilation
data.content: Breathing that is very quick and shallow; also called over breathing

data.title: Hypoventilation
data.content: Breathing rhythm is too low and the amount of carbon dioxide concentration in the lungs is too high to be removed with normal breathing

data.title: Inspiratory capacity (IC)
data.content: The maximum amount that can be inhaled after a typical TV exhalation: IC = TV + IRV

data.title: Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
data.content: The amount that can be inhaled forcefully after a typical tidal inhalation.

data.title: Larynx
data.content: “Voice box”, composed mainly of cartilage, voluntary muscle, and vocal cords, used for breathing, swallowing, and talking

data.title: Nasal cavity
data.content: Found above the bone that forms the roof of the mouth,  lined with a mucus-producing, ciliated epithelium, joins with the throat

data.title: Obstructive airway conditions
data.content: Make it difficult to exhale a normal volume of air

data.title: Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR)
data.content: The maximum air flow attained during a maximum forced expiration following a maximum inhalation

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The “throat”, a muscular passage way

data.title: Physiological dead space
data.content: Air not involved in gas exchange; also called total dead space

data.title: Pleural cavity
data.content: Space between the pleural membranes of the lung, reduces friction between the membranes as they slide past one another with each breath

data.title: Residual volume (RV)
data.content: The amount of air remaining in the lungs after a forceful exhalation

data.title: Respiratory acidosis
data.content: When lungs can't remove carbon dioxide

data.title: Respiratory alkalosis
data.content: Occurs as a result of hyperventilation, carbon dioxide levels drop too low

data.title: Respiratory capacities
data.content: Gauges of respiratory function calculated by adding two or more lung volumes

data.title: Respiratory rate (RR)
data.content: The number of breaths per minute

data.title: Respiratory volume
data.content: Measurement of the amount of air in the lungs

data.title: Restrictive airway conditions
data.content: Restrict lung expansion, thus reducing overall lung volume and, consequently, measurements including inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes and residual volume

data.title: Tachypnea
data.content: Rapid breathing with a rate above 20 breaths per minute

data.title: Tidal volume (TV)
data.content: The amount drawn into and exhaled from the lungs during a typical breath when one is at rest

data.title: Total lung capacity (TLC)
data.content: The maximum amount the lungs can hold with the deepest possible inhalation: TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

data.title: Trachea
data.content: The “windpipe”, a tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage,  extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes

data.title: Vital capacity (VC)
data.content: The maximum amount that can be expelled from the lungs after a forceful inhalation: VC = TV + IRV + ERV
